 TilePattern[] naiveDifferences(TilePattern[] patterns)
          compares this TilePattern to a specified TilePattern and list the difference This is a one-way function, analysing how much the foreign patterns needs to be changed in order for it to match this pattern.

complexDifferences

public RequiredTilePattern[] complexDifferences(TilePattern[] patterns,
                                                TilePattern[] differences)
Calculates a difference score between this pattern and a set of target patterns, provided the simple tile differences is known.

Parameters:
patterns - The patterns that can be played for
differences - The difference patterns between those, and the available hand
Returns:
RequiredTilePattern[] array representing the set of required tiles for each pattern-difference pair

complexGenericDifference

private RequiredTilePattern complexGenericDifference(TilePattern pattern,
                                                     TilePattern difference)
compute which tiles are required to make the target patterns match up to this pattern.

Parameters:
pattern - the target pattern
difference - the difference between the current hand and the target
Returns:
a RequiredTilePattern marking which tiles will be required to turn the current hand into the target pattern

createMergedPattern

public static TilePattern createMergedPattern(TilePattern first,
                                              TilePattern second)
creates a new TilePattern with the merged generic and specific values of two other TilePatterns

Parameters:
first - master TilePattern
second - merge TilePattern
Returns:
A TilePattern representing the merger of these two

createPattern

public static TilePattern createPattern(int type,
                                        int[] generic,
                                        int[][] specific)
static factory for generating TilePatterns

Parameters:
type - TilePattern.GENERIC or TilePattern.SPECIFIC
generic - the generic int[] container for the to-be-created TilePattern
specific - the specific int[][] container for the to-be-created TilePattern
Returns:
A new TilePattern with specified generic and specific containers

public static int[] generateEmptyGeneric()
generates an empty genericbins structure

Returns:
an empty generic int[] container

generateEmptySpecific

public static int[][] generateEmptySpecific()
generates an empty specificbins structure

Returns:
an empty specific int[][] container

getGenericValue

public int getGenericValue(int bin)
return the value of a generic bin

Parameters:
bin - any of the types in genericnames
Returns:
the number of entries in the corresponding specificbin list

getPatternType

public int getPatternType()
return the pattern type for this pattern: generic or specific. a generic pattern matches differently from a specific pattern.

Returns:
either GENERIC or SPECIFIC

getRecomputedGenericValue

public int getRecomputedGenericValue(int bin)
return the value of a generic bin, recomputed from the content of its specificbin equivalent.

Parameters:
bin - any of the types in genericnames
Returns:
a presence count rather than the actual content number

getSpecificValues

public int[] getSpecificValues(int bin)
return the value array of a specific bin

Parameters:
bin - any of the types in genericnames
Returns:
the int[] array in this specific bin

getSpecificValue

public int getSpecificValue(int bin,
                            int tile)
return the value of a single tile in a specific bin

Parameters:
bin - any of the types in genericnames
tile - the check tile number
Returns:
the value for the check tile in the specific bin

length

public int length()
checks how many tiles are in this pattern

naiveDifference

private TilePattern naiveDifference(TilePattern pattern)
determine the difference between this pattern, and a target pattern, where the difference is expressed as changes required to turn the foreign pattern in the local pattern

Parameters:
pattern - the comparison pattern
Returns:
a TilePattern representing the naive difference between the comparison pattern, and this one

naiveDifferences

public TilePattern[] naiveDifferences(TilePattern[] patterns)
compares this TilePattern to a specified TilePattern and list the difference This is a one-way function, analysing how much the foreign patterns needs to be changed in order for it to match this pattern.

Parameters:
patterns - a TilePattern[] array representing the collection of possible to play for patterns
Returns:
a TilePattern[] array representing the corresponding naive difference patterns

scoreTilePattern

public void scoreTilePattern(int tile,
                             int pattern)
adds a score to a particular generic pattern, and for which tile this pattern applies

Parameters:
pattern -

protected void setGenericBins(int[] generic)
forcefully set the generic int[] container

Parameters:
generic - the new generic int[] container

public int getScore()
consult this pattern's score

Returns:
this pattern's score

setScore

public void setScore(int score)
score this pattern

Parameters:
score - this pattern's score

setSpecificBins

protected void setSpecificBins(int[][] specific)
forcefully set the specific int[][] container

Parameters:
specific - the new specific int[][] container

standardWinPattern

public static TilePattern standardWinPattern()
create the "standard" win pattern pair + 4 sets

Returns:
the standard win pattern, modelled as a TilePattern

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
toString method

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

getDFSAlist

public int[][] getDFSAlist(boolean concealed)
get the DFSAlist associated with this pattern

Parameters:
concealed - flag to determine whether we want the face up or concealed dfsalist
Returns:
the int[][] (see formDFA) list representing this hand - normal list if concealed was false, concealed list if it was true

forceFormDFSAlist

public void forceFormDFSAlist()

formDFSAlist

private void formDFSAlist()
turns the tile pattern as stored in this pattern into an int[][] list that can be understood by the dynamic FSA system used for scoring. It creates two of these lists, one for if the pattern is to be considered "face up", and one for "concealed".
